narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strong understanding of how the so-called "scientific revolution" is a simplistic, eurocentric view of the scientific method's development

I learned about the misconceptions and oversimplifications of current views of the early modern period, and I learned about the complex relationships between religion and science during the Scientific Revolution.

This course takes a multi-disciplinary look at the Scientific Revolution, interrogating the term and diving in to a different facet of it each week. Some of the topics covered include: astrology, astronomy, natural history, and anatomy.
This course challenged the traditional notion of the "scientific revolution" and introduced us to the broad variety of scientific disciplines practiced in the early modern period.
How to contextualize primary sources with the ideas of the scientific revolution
Better understanding of the fallacies of the scientific revolution narrative and the reasons behind the myth-making
Analysis of the scientific revolution in context

I gained a great overview in the history of science through the 18th century. I gained insight into belief systems and epistemology, scientific methods, technology, the way ideas were communicated, the context of society and the church in a variety of topics from anatomy to natural history to astronomy to alchemy. I also gained intro experience to historiographic methods and writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Dal Prete was largely an engaging lecturer, but sometimes he went on tangents that were a little bit distracting and made it hard to tell which parts of lecture were important

Strengths: course structure, discussion section 
Weaknesses: difficulty making connections between readings and lecture

The course was overall really great! The only complaint I have is that it felt like we spent too much time on some topics at the expense of others. For example: we spent at least 4 lectures talking about astronomy and it probably could have been condensed into 2.
Theme of the class is interesting - I like that the course challenged what has been popularized as the "scientific revolution."

Strengths: Good variety of topics and readings
Weaknesses: Too much analysis of art work instead of learning of the science itself
Sometimes lectures were too narrowly focused and the bigger picture takeaways were not super evident

Strengths: Nuanced discussion of a wide variety of interesting topics.
Weaknesses: Some sections felt a bit too fast-paced, some a bit too repetitive (but this could just be based on my own interests). Could maybe contextualize the readings more. It would have been nice to have open office hours. The purpose of section was not always clear.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish there were more opportunities for student engagement
Professor Dal Prete made a great effort to allow us to ask questions and have discussions during class.
Lots of availability during office hours.

It was difficult to engage in the lecture virtually, but Professor Dal Prete did a great job under the circumstances and welcomed questions. He also utilized the virtual medium for his lectures by making engaging slides that often had video.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but make sure you are ready to put some serious thought (if not too much time) into understanding the readings and lectures' themes; it is not always straightforward

Yes, especially for STEM students! Learning about how humans have viewed science and knowledge making throughout time is super interesting and really gives current STEM students a valuable perspective to use in other studies.
Absolutely!! If you are focusing on early modern Europe at all in your studies, this course is for you. It gave me so much context that I didnt realize I was missing. Highly recommend!
Yes! Good balance of historical information/overview and more open-ended themes and questions.
Yes
Yes the content was super important and shifted my understanding of the progress narrative quite a bit
No, there were a lot of changes midway through the semester with the syllabus.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in the history and/or philosophy of science. As a STEM major, I felt like I got a great intro to elements of history that I've always been curious about, and I was able to spend time thinking about the implicit assumptions we make in the modern world about scientific knowledge now and in the past. The readings were mostly pretty interesting, the writing assignments very manageable, and the exams fair.
